general: Teicoplanin is a parenteral glycopeptide, similar to Vancomycin, available in Europe, Asia-Pacific and Africa.
In U.S. trials, doses needed to clear Staph. aureus bacteremia were toxic with the most common adverse event being the development of thrombocytopenia. Not licensed for use in the U.S.
An alternative antibiotic for drug resistant genotypes.
Can be administered intramuscularly (max 400 mg at any site).

pediatric_dose.age_0_to_le_2_mon: 16 mg/kg IV x1 dose, then 8 mg/kg IV q24h
pediatric_dose.age_2_mon_to_12_yrs: 10 mg/kg IV q12h x3 doses, then 6-10 mg/kg IV q24h

renal_adjustment.dose_renal_function_normal: 6-12 mg/kg IV q12h x3 doses (load), then 6-12 mg/kg IV q24h
renal_adjustment.crcl_or_egfr: CrCl >80: No dosage adjustment. CrCl 30-80: Load, then 6-12 mg/kg q48h. CrCl <30: Load, then 6-12 mg/kg q72h

other_adjustment: ECMO: See ECMO Drug Dosing Adjustment table.
Obesity: See Obesity Dosing Adjustments table.
adverse_effects: Hypersensitivity: fever (at 3 mg/kg 2.2%, at 24 mg/kg 8.2%), skin reactions (2.4%).
Marked decrease in platelets (high dose ≥15 mg/kg/day); anemia and neutropenia can occur.
Histamine-release syndrome less common than with Vancomycin.

pregnancy_risk.lactation: Unknown if excreted into breast milk. Use only if potential benefit outweighs risk.
pregnancy_risk.footnote: Capital letter = Old FDA risk category; Text = New FDA risk category

preferred: Staphylococcus sp., coagulase-negative (Methicillin resistant); S. hominis, S. capitis, others

major_drug_interactions: Use caution in patients receiving concurrent nephrotoxic or ototoxic drugs, such as aminoglycosides, amphotericin B, cyclosporine and furosemide.
comments: In endocarditis, Teicoplanin has often been used in combination regimens.
